title: What Is Gastroparesis?

content: Gastroparesis is a disorder that affects the nerves and muscles in your stomach and stalls the movement of food to the small intestine. Under normal conditions, muscles in your stomach help to break down food into smaller pieces. These same muscles also push the food farther along, moving them to the small intestine for more digestion. In gastroparesis, food can remain in your stomach for too long and cause problems.

Gastroparesis affects about four times as many women as men, but overall, the condition isn’t common. However, if you have diabetes, you’re more likely to develop gastroparesis; about 1/3 of all cases are related to type 1 or type 2 diabetes. Gastroparesis caused by diabetes happens because consistently elevated blood glucose levels damage the nerves in the stomach. In addition, high blood glucose concentrations also harm the blood vessels that transport oxygen and nutrients to stomach muscles.

There are other reasons for gastroparesis. People with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), those who’ve had surgery on their stomach, small intestine, or esophagus, those with certain nervous system disorders, including Parkinson’s disease and multiple sclerosis, or people who have had radiation therapy for cancer to their stomach or chest areas are more likely to have gastroparesis.

content: Infections of the intestinal tract, including norovirus and rotavirus, can also trigger gastroparesis, although experts aren’t sure why. Autoimmune diseases, such as lupus and celiac disease, can also cause gastroparesis even if the autoimmune disease has nothing to do with the stomach.

Certain drugs, including those used for recreation, block the signals that tell your stomach muscles to break down food and push it along. Medications that cause temporary gastroparesis include opioids, marijuana, calcium channel blockers used to treat high blood pressure, and a class of antidepressants called tricyclic antidepressants.

Weight loss and diabetes drugs containing semaglutide (Ozempic and Wegovy, for example) slow down the gastrointestinal tract so that you feel fuller on less food. Some people experience gastroparesis when they take these and other medications known as GLP-1 agonists. If you have poor stomach movement or are at risk for it, you may want to try alternative weight loss medications.

sections.heading: Symptoms of Gastroparesis
content: Gastroparesis symptoms vary. When food sits in your stomach for too long, you may get fuller faster on less food and for longer. Stomachaches are commonplace, as is nausea and vomiting. You may feel bloated after eating even a small meal, and it’s possible to have acid reflux that irritates your esophagus, the tube that leads from your mouth to your stomach.

content: Upper abdominal pain is another sign of gastroparesis, sometimes to the point of interfering with your daily life. Bloating is a symptom of gastroparesis, as is spitting up large pieces of undigested food.

Because it’s difficult to eat and drink, there’s the potential for several health problems with gastroparesis. You may not eat enough nutrient-rich food, which can lead to weight loss and malnutrition.  If you’re vomiting, dehydration can result.

People with diabetes may experience blood glucose ups and downs with gastroparesis because it impedes the regular flow of energy from digested food that helps keep blood glucose levels steady. When food is stuck in the stomach, blood glucose drops very low, but it can also go too high once the intestinal tract starts digesting it.

Bezoars are another problem with gastroparesis. A bezoar is a compact, hardened mass of food stuck in the stomach. It forms out of pieces that are left behind when the stomach empties. A bezoar may become too big to pass through the outlet at the bottom of the stomach that leads to the small intestine. Bezoars can also block this opening and make it hard for other food to pass through. They may result in ulcers and bleeding.

sections.heading: How Gastroparesis Is Diagnosed
content: Tell your doctor about all your symptoms, medications, and any medical conditions you have. Health care providers typically use imaging tests, such as an upper endoscopy or ultrasound, to look at your stomach and determine if something is blocking it. If there’s nothing in the way, you’ll likely have tests to evaluate the activity of your stomach muscles. You may have additional tests, such as a blood test, to get to the cause of your gastroparesis.

sections.heading: Treating Gastroparesis
content: There’s no cure for gastroparesis. Medications that stimulate stomach muscles to move are used most often to manage gastroparesis. If you have gastroparesis, work with a registered dietitian nutritionist (RDN) who’s an expert in gastrointestinal issues. An RDN can help you adjust your diet and lifestyle to help manage symptoms and avoid complications related to poor nutrition, dehydration, and abnormally high or low blood glucose levels. Avoiding alcohol, smoking and tobacco in any form, and recreational drugs can help your discomfort. Everyone’s approach to managing gastroparesis will be different, but it may help to avoid eating large meals. Consuming modest amounts of dietary fat and fiber can also be beneficial. Fat and fiber take longer to digest and contribute to slower stomach emptying.
